name: Alice Duer Miller
biographical_notes: American poet, novelist, and screenwriter (1874-1942). Born in Staten Island, died in NYC. Prominent suffragist who wrote political verse for the New York Tribune (1914-1917). Member of the Algonquin Round Table and Heterodoxy. Best known for _The White Cliffs_ which sold over 200,000 copies in first 2 years. One of the first East Coast authors imported to Hollywood by Samuel Goldwyn (1921); worked for Paramount, RKO, and MGM over 20 years.
author_notes: also wrote under the pseud Clara Bartram

name: Edna Ferber
literary_movement: Popular fiction, historical novels, regional literature, social realism, Broadway theater
biographical_notes: Edna Ferber (1885-1968) was one of America's most successful and adapted authors, winning the Pulitzer Prize for _So Big_ (1925). Her sweeping American historical epics, which Hollywood repeatedly adapted, centered working women and reflected her commitment to multiracial justice. Member of the Algonquin Round Table, she collaborated with fellow member George S. Kaufman on hit plays. Never married, fiercely independent, she began as a teenage reporter and became one of the first authors to negotiate rights reversions and profit participation in Hollywood. Her novel _Ice Palace_ was credited with helping Alaska achieve statehood. Despite critical dismissal as "middlebrow," her progressive racial politics and feminist perspective made her work pioneering. Co-founded Giant Productions, achieving rare creative control for a writer in 1950s Hollywood.
key_themes: ["women's independence", 'American history', 'racial justice', 'working women', 'regional life', 'social class', 'family sagas', 'ambition', 'multiracial America', 'Jewish-American experience']
education: Ryan High School, Appleton, Wisconsin (graduated 1903). No college education; began working as a reporter at age 17 for the Appleton Daily Crescent.
key_associations: ['George S. Kaufman', 'Leland Hayward', 'Samuel Goldwyn', 'George Stevens', 'Irving Thalberg (early buyer)', 'Doubleday', 'Alexander Woollcott', 'Henry Ginsberg (Giant Productions partner)']
major_awards: ['Pulitzer Prize for Fiction (1925, So Big)', 'Honorary Doctorate from Columbia University (1931)', 'Chicago Literary Hall of Fame (2013, posthumous)', 'National Institute of Arts and Letters member']
archives_locations: ['State Historical Society of Wisconsin, Wisconsin Center for Film and Theater Research, Madison']
modern_availability: Her major works are available in modern reprints; sound-era films largely survive in good quality. Giant (1956) was restored by the Film Foundation in the 21st century.

name: Fannie Hurst
literary_movement: Popular magazine fiction, urban realism, melodrama, women's fiction, social problem novels
biographical_notes: Fannie Hurst (1889-1968) was one of America's highest-paid and most-adapted writers, defining the "women's picture" genre in Hollywood. After 35 rejections from _The Saturday Evening Post_, she broke through to become a fixture in major magazines. Her melodramas centered working-class women, immigrants, and forbidden love. Kept her 1915 marriage secret for 5 years and maintained separate residences from her husband for almost 40 years, modeling what became known as a "Fannie Hurst marriage." Friend of Eleanor Roosevelt, she served on New Deal committees including National Housing Commission. Hired Zora Neale Hurston as secretary. Helped raise money for Jewish refugees escaping Nazi Germany. Advocated for women's rights, racial justice, and gay rights. Despite critical dismissal as "lowbrow" (mocked by F. Scott Fitzgerald, Mel Brooks, and others), her 27 Hollywood adaptations reached millions. Donated millions to university creative writing programs. A complicated figure whose racial representations were both progressive and problematic for their time.
key_themes: ['working women', 'immigrant experience', 'forbidden love', 'maternal sacrifice', 'urban life', 'class mobility', 'racial dynamics', "women's independence", 'melodrama', 'suffering and redemption']
education: Washington University in St. Louis, Bachelor of Arts (1909). Attended but did not complete graduate work at Columbia University.
key_associations: ['Eleanor Roosevelt', 'Zora Neale Hurston', 'Carl Van Vechten', 'Jacques S. Danielson (husband)', 'William Randolph Hearst (Cosmopolitan)', 'Saturday Evening Post editors', 'New Deal administration', 'Authors Guild']
major_awards: ['O. Henry Prize (1919)', 'Multiple inclusions in Best American Short Stories', 'Honorary doctorates from Washington University and Columbia']

name: Gene Stratton-Porter
biographical_notes:
Gene Stratton-Porter (1863–1924) was an American novelist, naturalist, photographer, and film producer whose nature romances dominated bestseller lists throughout the 1910s and 1920s. Born Geneva Grace Stratton in Wabash County, Indiana, she did not complete high school but became a self-taught naturalist and photographer. She was an innovative nature photographer who captured images of live birds at a time when most naturalists only studied them stuffed and mounted.

Her breakthrough novel _Freckles_ (1904) launched a literary career that made her into "a public institution, like Yellowstone Park," as William Lyon Phelps put in in 1921. She specialized in sentimental romances set in closely observed natural settings, particularly Indiana's Limberlost region. When critics accused her of writing "molasses fiction," she embraced the label, declaring that molasses was "more necessary to the happiness of human and beast than vinegar." By the time of her death, she was a columnist for both _Good Housekeeping_ and _McCall's_ magazines.

Disappointed by Paramount's 1917 adaptation of _Freckles_, Stratton-Porter took unprecedented action: she moved to Los Angeles and founded Gene Stratton Porter Productions in 1923-24. At her studio, she wrote scenarios and maintained creative control over her adaptations. She died in a Los Angeles streetcar accident in December 1924, having completed work on only her first independent productions. Her studio continued under her daughter Jeannette Porter Meehan's leadership through 1927, ultimately producing five films.

Though critics dismissed her work, her unique combination of popular fiction and authentic natural detail, along with her unprecedented move into film production, makes her a significant figure in both literary and film history.
key_themes: ['nature romance', 'conservation', 'Indiana wilderness', 'orphan narratives', 'moral uplift', 'rural life', 'natural history', 'Limberlost swamp']
education: Self-educated; did not complete high school but extensively studied nature, photography, and ornithology independently
key_associations: ["women's club movement", 'Good Housekeeping', "McCall's", 'Jeannette Porter Meehan (daughter)', 'James Leo Meehan (son-in-law)']
archives_locations: ['Indiana State University Library', 'Lilly Library at Indiana University', 'Gene Stratton-Porter State Historic Sites (Indiana)', 'private collections (majority of papers)']
modern_availability: All but her last novels are in the public domain. Few of her films are accessible today, and those few are mostly available in poor-quality transfers from video.

name: Mary Roberts Rinehart
literary_movement: Popular fiction, mystery fiction, early 20th century magazine culture
biographical_notes: Mary Roberts Rinehart (1876-1958) was a permanent fixture on bestseller lists during her career, which spanned  a half-century. A trained nurse who turned to writing after her husband's financial troubles, she revolutionized the mystery genre by adding humor, romance, and psychological depth. As a WWI correspondent, she used her nursing credentials to access the front lines when women reporters were banned. Her story _The Circular Staircase_ and its theatrical adaptation _The Bat_ may have inspired Batman. Despite critical dismissal as "middlebrow," she was the most adapted American woman writer in Hollywood history.
education: Pittsburgh Training School for Nurses at Pittsburgh Homeopathic Hospital (graduated 1896)
key_associations: ['Stanley Marshall Rinehart (husband)', 'Farrar & Rinehart publishers', 'Samuel Goldwyn', "Munsey's Magazine", 'The Saturday Evening Post', 'All-Story Magazine']
major_awards: ['Mystery Writers of America Special Award (1954)', 'regular bestseller list appearances 1909-1940s']
archives_locations: ['University of Pittsburgh Libraries Archives & Special Collections']
modern_availability: Public domain works are available online; many of her mystery novels have been reprinted by Penzler's American Mystery Classics.

name: Winifred Wolfe
biographical_notes: American writer, screenwriter and playwright (1923-1981). Born in Boston. Died in Manhattan. Occupations: screenwriter, writer, playwright

name: Zoe Akins
biographical_notes: Playwright, poet, author. Born in Humansville. Died in Los Angeles. Occupations: playwright, writer, poet, screenwriter

name: Zona Gale
biographical_notes: American author and playwright. Born in Portage. Died in Chicago. Occupations: short story writer, suffragist, writer, playwright, novelist. Notable works: Miss Lulu Bett
